workflow.name: Extract & organize email invoices with Gmail, Drive & OpenAI GPT
workflow.description:
## Who’s it for

This template is for founders, finance teams, and solo operators who receive lots of invoices by email and want them captured automatically in a single, searchable source of truth. If you’re tired of hunting through your inbox for invoice PDFs or “that one receipt from three months ago,” this is for you.

## What it does / How it works

The workflow polls your Gmail inbox on a schedule and fetches new messages including their attachments. A JavaScript Code node restructures all attachments, and a PDF extraction node reads any attached PDFs.  
An AI “Invoice Recognition Agent” then analyzes the email body and attachments to decide whether the email actually contains an invoice. If not, the workflow stops.

If it is an invoice, a second AI “Invoice Data Extractor” pulls structured fields such as `date_email`, `date_invoice`, `invoice_nr`, `description`, `provider`, `net_amount`, `vat`, `gross_amount`, `label` (saas/hardware/other), and `currency`. Depending on whether the invoice is in an attachment or directly in the email text, the workflow either:

- uploads the invoice file to Google Drive, or  
- document a direct link to the mail,

then appends/updates a row in Google Sheets with all invoice parameters plus a Drive link, and finally marks the Gmail message as read.

## How to set up

1. Add and authenticate:
   - Gmail credentials  
   - Google Sheets credentials  
   - Google Drive credentials  
   - OpenAI (or compatible) credentials for the AI nodes
2. Create or select a Google Sheet with the expected columns (date_email, date_invoice, invoice_nr, description, provider, net_amount, vat, gross_amount, label, currency, link).
3. Create or select a Google Drive folder where invoices/docs should be stored.
4. Adjust the Gmail Trigger filters (labels, search query, polling interval) to match the mailbox you want to process.
5. Update node credentials and resource IDs (Sheet, Drive folder) via the node UIs, not hardcoded in HTTP nodes.

## Requirements

- n8n instance (cloud or self-hosted)  
- Gmail account with OAuth2 setup  
- Google Drive and Google Sheets access  
- OpenAI (or compatible) API key configured in n8n  
- Sufficient permissions to read emails, read/write Drive files, and edit the target Sheet

## How to customize the workflow

- **Change invoice categories**: Extend the `label` enum (e.g., add “services”, “subscriptions”) in the extraction schema and adjust any downstream logic.
- **Refine invoice detection**: Tweak the AI prompts to be more or less strict about what counts as an invoice or receipt.
- **Add notifications**: After updating the Sheet, send a Slack/Teams message or email summary for high-value invoices.
- **Filter by sender or subject**: Narrow the Gmail Trigger to specific vendors, labels, or keywords.
- **Extend the data model**: Add fields (e.g., cost center, project code) to the extractor prompt and Sheet mapping to fit your bookkeeping setup.

parameters.name: =Invoice_{{ $('Document the invoice parameters').item.json.provider }}_{{ $('Document the invoice parameters').item.json.date_invoice }}

parameters.text:
=You are a precise email classifier. Your task: determine if the email includes an invoice in the message body and/or as an attachment. Be strict and evidence-based.


Definitions
Invoice: A document requesting payment for goods/services, typically with supplier details, invoice number, issue date, due date/terms, line items or description, and a total amount (with currency). Includes “tax invoice.” Credit notes/debit notes count as invoice-like if they settle or adjust an invoice.
Not invoices: quotes/estimates, pro forma invoices (unless explicitly used as the payable document in that context), order confirmations, purchase orders, statements of account, shipping notices, delivery notes, receipts (unless your policy treats receipts as invoices—see Policy toggle), marketing emails, reminders without the invoice attached or shown.
Policy toggle: include_receipts = true if the receipt includes net, gross and a tax rate and fals if the receipt only includes payment confirmation without net; gross and vat rale.
Languages and synonyms (non-exhaustive)
EN: invoice, tax invoice, bill, credit note, debit note, inv, inv#
DE: Rechnung, Gutschrift
FR: facture, avoir
ES/PT: factura/fatura, nota de crédito
IT: fattura, nota di credito
NL: factuur, creditnota
PL/CZ: faktura
Nordics: faktura
FI: lasku
TR: fatura
EL: τιμολόγιο
RU: счёт-фактура
AR: فاتورة
ZH: 发票, 账单
JA: 請求書
KO: 세금계산서, 인보이스
Recognize abbreviations and filename hints: INV_2025-001.pdf, Rechnung_12345, Facture-2025, Fattura_345, faktura_*.pdf.

Attachments to consider
Documents: pdf, pdf/a, doc, docx, xls, xlsx, csv
Images: jpg/jpeg, png, tiff/tif, heic
Archives: zip, rar, 7z (assume unknown unless contents listed)
Emails: eml, msg (may contain invoice attachments)
E-invoice/XML: xml (UBL 2.x, PEPPOL BIS, XRechnung, Factur-X/ZUGFeRD), json
If text extraction is unavailable (e.g., images, password-protected PDFs), rely on filename, MIME type, and surrounding body text cues. Do not assume OCR unless content is provided.
Positive body indicators (examples)
“Invoice”, “Tax Invoice”, “Rechnung”, “Facture”, “Fattura”, “Factuur”, “Faktura”, “請求書”
Patterns like: Invoice No/Number/ID, INV-xxxx, Rechnungsnr., PO/Order reference, Due date/Net 30, VAT/Tax ID, subtotal/total, currency symbols/ISO codes (USD, EUR, GBP)
Clear payable context: “Amount due”, “Please find attached invoice”, “Your invoice for [period]”
Negative/ambiguous cases (do NOT count as invoice unless clearly attached/shown)
Approval reminders without the actual invoice
Payment confirmations/receipts (default excluded)
Quotes/estimates/pro forma (unless also a payable invoice is present)
Monthly statements or balance summaries
Shipping/tracking notifications
Links to a portal to download the invoice (no in-body invoice, no attachment = NOT present)
Spam/fraud cues with no concrete invoice content
Decision rules
Body = YES if the email body itself includes enough structured indicators that it is the invoice (e.g., labeled invoice, supplier details, invoice number/date, total due). A single phrase like “invoice below” without the actual invoice details is NOT enough.
Attachment = YES if any attachment is very likely an invoice based on filename, type, or extracted content. For images or locked PDFs with no text, use filename + body context to decide likelihood.
Both = If invoice appears in body and an invoice file is attached.
Neither = If none of the above applies.
Unsure = If evidence is insufficient or contradictory.
Be conservative. Support your decision with concrete evidence snippets (short quotes, filenames). Prefer “Neither” or “Unsure” over guessing.

Use null for unknown extracted fields.
If multiple candidate attachments exist, include all in evidence. If multiple invoices are present, mention in notes.
Examples
Example 1 (Attachment = YES):

Subject: “Invoice INV-1045 for March”
Body: “Please find attached invoice INV-1045. Due in 14 days.”
Attachments: INV-1045.pdf (application/pdf)
Expected:
contains_invoice: "yes", location: "attachment", confidence: ~0.95
Evidence cites filename “INV-1045.pdf” and body cue “attached invoice INV-1045”
Example 2 (Body = YES):

Body includes: “Tax Invoice”, “Invoice No: 2025-033”, supplier details, total = “€1,240.00”
No attachments.
Expected:
contains_invoice: "yes", location: "body", confidence: high
Evidence cites invoice number, total, and header “Tax Invoice”
Example 3 (Neither):

Body: “Your monthly statement is ready. Log in to download your invoices.”
No attachments.
Expected:
contains_invoice: "no", location: "neither", confidence: high
Example 4 (Unsure):

Subject: “Rechnung”
Body: “Hier ist es.”
Attachment: image_1234.png (no text extraction)
Expected:
contains_invoice: "unsure" or "yes" (low confidence) depending on filename/body context; note OCR unavailability.
Additional guidelines
Ignore email signatures, legal disclaimers, and marketing footers.
If the email only contains a link to fetch the invoice, classify as “no/neither”.
For forwarded chains, if an earlier message includes an invoice in its body or as a nested attachment, you may classify accordingly and note it.
If policy include_receipts = true, treat “Receipt”/“Payment receipt” with clear amount and supplier as invoices; otherwise exclude.

E-Mail Elements:
subject: {{ $('Get a message').all()[0].json.subject }}
text: {{ $('Get a message').all()[0].json.text }}
From: {{ $('Get a message').all()[0].json.headers.from }}
Date: {{ $('Get a message').all()[0].json.headers.date }}

Attachment text extraction (if available):
{{ $json.text }}

nodes.name: Check wether it is an invoice

parameters.content:
## Gmail Trigger based on user customized interval
**then get the gmail parameter inclusive text and attachments and extract all pdf files from attachments with js-code

## Extract the text from the pdf attachment if exists
**otherwise ignore and further process

## Analyse the context of the mail and the attachments and process further in case it is an invoice
**otherwise ignore and stop the process

## Extract the relevant invoice parameters
**date_email, date_invoice, invoice_nr, description, provider, net_amount, vat, gross_amount, label, currency

nodes.name: Check wether it was a file-invoice or text invoice

parameters.content: ## Was the invoice in attachments or in the mail body?
## Document the paramters in sheet, uoload the invoice file to drive and update the sheet with the invoice-url in your drive, and finally mark the invoice message as read in you gmail
## Document the paramters in sheet, generate a link to the email

data.details:
The IF node can be used to implement binary conditional logic in your workflow. You can set up one-to-many conditions to evaluate each item of data being inputted into the node. That data will either evaluate to TRUE or FALSE and route out of the node accordingly.

This node has multiple types of conditions: Bool, String, Number, and Date & Time.
